title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.17.2 | 13-02-2023
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiraandasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chaksharunmeelitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual master and deities.

segments.key_quote: The bull was as white as a white lotus flower. He was terrified of the Shudra.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam describing the bull (Dharma) in the age of Kali, emphasizing its fear and trembling.

segments.key_quote: The next symptom of the age of Kali is that principles of religion which are all spotlessly white like the white lotus flower will be attacked by the uncultured Shudra population of the age.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the bull represents religious principles and the Shudra represents the uncultured population of Kali Yuga who attack these principles.

segments.key_quote: Without such a purificatory process, the children born will be uncultured, will have criminal mentality.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of cultural purification rituals like Garbha Dhana for conceiving good children, contrasting it with the lack of such practices in Kali Yuga, leading to an uncultured population.

segments.key_quote: But in Kalyuga, the Shudra class of people who are uncultured, they will not follow the religious principles as it is.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates that in Kali Yuga, the uncultured Shudra population defies religious principles due to a lack of education and Vedic wisdom.

segments.key_quote: This sort of attitude is killing the whole vitality of the human population in this age of Kali.
segments.summary: The speaker compares following religious principles to obeying state laws, highlighting how defiance and lack of Vedic knowledge contribute to the decline of society in Kali Yuga.

segments.key_quote: They also harass others who want to follow the religious principles. They will decry them.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses how those who defy religious principles harass and discourage those who try to follow them, exploiting the concept of freedom in the name of religion.

segments.key_quote: So why one religious system says you should not kill innocent animals another system will say oh as as far as eating is eating habits are concerned that's the person's choice
segments.summary: The speaker criticizes the proliferation of unfounded religious systems in Kali Yuga, using the example of animal killing to illustrate the lack of a proper basis for these systems and the secular nature of the state.

segments.key_quote: But in Kali Yuga, in the name of secularism there will be no religious principles which are proper principles which will be followed by people.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the indifference to real religious principles in Kali Yuga, emphasizing the lack of respect for truthfulness, saintly persons (sadhu), scriptures (shastra), and spiritual masters (guru).

segments.key_quote: People don't care for religious principles. Even if there is a deterioration or decline, they just don't bother.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by highlighting the diminishing state of religious principles and the lack of concern for this decline, emphasizing the link between God consciousness and societal peace and prosperity.
